subject: Art & Design
title: Brutalism: Concrete as Art
description: A quick, practical guide to Brutalism: Concrete as Art.

hook.text: Massive, raw concrete slabs. No ornamentation. Brutalist buildings are loved and hated in equal measure.

buildup.text: Brutalism (1950sâ€“70s) used exposed concrete ('bÃ©ton brut') and bold geometric forms. It was deliberately unrefined.

discovery.text: Born from post-war rebuilding, Brutalism offered honest, affordable structures for public housing and civic buildings.

twist.text: Most people found Brutalist buildings cold and oppressive. Many were demolished. Now they're being listed as heritage.

climax.text: The Barbican in London and Habitat 67 in Montreal are now celebrated icons of the movement.

punchline.text: Brutalism asked: can raw honesty be beautiful? The debate rages on.
